I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will facilitate demand for local 
currency-denominated (LCY) bonds in members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
(ASEAN) plus the People’s Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea (collectively 
known as ASEAN+3).1 The TA aims to strengthen information dissemination and raise awareness 
among bond investors to promote demand for LCY bonds as part of the Asian Bond Markets 
Initiative (ABMI). 
 
2.  The TA follows the guidance of Strategy 2030 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and 
the ABMI Medium-Term Road Map, 2019–2022. The TA aligns with the ADB Strategy 2030 
operation  plan  for  priority  7:  Fostering  regional  cooperation  and  integration  (2019–2024), 
particularly its second pillar (global and regional trade and investment opportunities expanded) 
and third sub-pillar (strengthening regional financial cooperation). The TA activities also align with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030 by producing public goods that increase regional finance sector cooperation 
and integration.2 Specifically, the TA generates publicly available information on regional bond 
markets and strengthens finance sector cooperation through regional bond market initiatives. 
Thus, these activities closely follow ADB’s key operational priorities in Strategy 2030—fostering 
regional  cooperation  and  integration—particularly  in  the  finance  sector  and  through  other 
subregional initiatives. 
 
3.  The TA will undertake its activities under ABMI Task Force 2, following the guidance of 
the ABMI road map, which was endorsed by ASEAN+3 governments in May 2019.3 The TA will 
upgrade  the  bond  market  data  portal,  the  AsianBondsOnline  (ABO)  website,  into  a 
comprehensive regional bond market information platform that disseminates a wide range of 
information—including market data, knowledge products, policy and regulatory changes, and 
recent market practices—from all ABMI task forces in an integrated and systematic way to 
facilitate communication with regional and global investors and issuers. As the primary information 
platform for ASEAN+3 bond markets, the enhanced ABO portal will better serve stakeholders 
within and outside ASEAN+3 member economies. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  A key lesson from the 1997–1998 Asian financial crisis was the need to develop LCY bond 
markets as an integral part of deeper, more liquid, and more balanced financial systems across 
the region. The crisis catalyzed the ASEAN+3 financial cooperation process, including ABMI and 
the Chiang Mai Initiative and its subsequent multilateralization. Since its launch in December 2002, 
ABMI has (i) helped develop regional LCY bond markets to mitigate the double mismatch 
(currency and maturity) problem at the heart of the 1997–1998 Asian financial crisis, and (ii) 
promoted  regional  financial  development  and  stability.  As  of  December  2019,  LCY  bonds 
outstanding in regional markets reached $16.0 trillion, a more than 14-fold increase since 2002. 
The  aggregate  size  of  the  region’s  LCY  bond  markets  is  now  approaching  that  of  euro-
denominated bond markets.4 In addition, sukuk (Islamic bond) markets and green bond financing 
are developing rapidly in the region.

2 
5.  Despite the rapid growth of emerging East Asian LCY bond markets, the region still lacks 
a well-diversified investor base, which limits the demand for LCY bonds and constrains financing 
for the region’s large infrastructure investment needs. A strong investor profile can enhance 
market liquidity, pricing efficiency, and resilience to external shocks. Within the region, some bond 
markets have limited foreign participation, while other markets lack a well-diversified domestic 
investor base. Many factors contribute to the lack of investor diversification, including weak 
institutional  factors,  inconsistent  legal  and  regulatory  practices,  less-developed  market 
infrastructures, relatively small investor bases, different levels of finance sector development, 
inconsistent credit rating practices, high transaction costs, and lack of market depth. 
 
6.  Information asymmetry. In addition to the factors listed above (para. 5), information 
asymmetry faced by bond market participants constrains the diversification of investor base. The 
lack of up-to-date information on regional bond markets is even more pronounced for small and 
frontier bond markets. Investors will avoid financial markets which entail greater information 
asymmetry. When investors face limited and unclear information on market development status, 
market access, and regulatory and policy practices, they will not invest. For example, many 
foreign investors requested information on how to invest in fast-growing emerging bond markets 
like Viet Nam.  Although the Viet Nam bond market welcomes foreign participants, investors 
lacked  timely  information  on  whether  they  can  invest,  how  to  invest,  and  relevant  market 
procedures and processes. The lack of timely information constrained the development of a well-
diversified investor base. Smaller, frontier regional bond markets have only limited publicly 
available bond market data; disseminating more information on bond market development will help 
mitigate this issue. For smaller ASEAN bond markets, a regional platform can more effectively 
disseminate information to investors. 
 
7.  Low levels of intraregional portfolio investments. ASEAN+3 has close intraregional 
economic linkages, but intraregional portfolio investments are relatively low, which limits the 
region’s ability to expand its investor base. The region’s limited cooperation and integration in 
finance arises from  different market practices  and regulations  and inconsistent  information 
disclosure  and  standards.  Further,  the  region’s  bond  markets  are  at  different  stages  of 
development and have different market structures. Some regional markets are at a relatively early 
stage of government bond market development, while others are now prioritizing corporate bond 
market  development,  enhancing  market  liquidity,  and  designing  hedging  instruments.  The 
relatively low level of intraregional portfolio flows also hinders regional bond markets from 
reaching a minimum efficient scale. To tackle this issue, ABO will enhance regional knowledge 
sharing  among  regional  bond  market  development  that  will  increase  communication  and 
collaboration among regional bond markets, boost common regional practices, and coordinate 
regulations. 
 
8.  ABMI has boosted regional bond market development on several fronts. Some activities 
promote the supply side by facilitating bond issuances, other initiatives improve bond market data 
and information dissemination, and yet other efforts enhance bond market infrastructure through 
harmonized market practices. Under ABMI Task Force 2, ABO disseminates information on 
regional bond markets and fosters demand for regional bond market instruments by disseminating 
comprehensive  up-to-date  information  that  focuses  on  regional  markets,  including  frontier 
regional bond markets. ABO also collaborates with regional government authorities to facilitate 
regional knowledge sharing on bond market development and updates investors and issuers on 
recent policy and regulation revisions. ABO’s key stakeholders include market participants as well 
as regulators and policy makers within and outside the region.

3 
9.  ADB has been serving as the ABMI secretariat and maintains the ABO website. During its 
years of operation and improvement, ABO gained wide recognition as the gateway to ASEAN+3 
bond market data. ABO information has been recognized and cited by the Group of Twenty (G20), 
the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and the World Bank, and used in commercial databases 
like Bloomberg. Compared with World Bank and IMF data, ABO offers more comprehensive, up-to-
date, and in-depth bond market information for ASEAN+3 markets. For example, the IMF Global 
Debt Database updated Malaysia data only to 2016 as of August 2019, while ABO updates data 
with a lag of only one quarter. Other commercial databases like Bloomberg collect data such as 
foreign holdings from ABO for regional bond markets. As a regional public good, ABO offers free 
bond market information that helps various stakeholders who cannot access costly commercial 
databases to gain information about regional bond markets. 
 
10.  During previous operations, a key lesson learned is to remain flexible and stay client-
oriented to better meet the demands of stakeholders. The TA builds on previous TA projects that 
have continuously enhanced ABO and improved user experience. Since ABO’s inception in 2004, 
earlier TA projects established the ABO website framework, set up the online database, and 
delivered knowledge products and services. After more than one decade, the ABO website began 
to fall behind fast advances in information technology. User survey feedback indicated demand 
for a website upgrade. Thus, under the current TA, the revamped ABO adopted a new database 
structure with an interactive interface. Instead of having to download the whole time series to their 
computers, users can now tailor their data requests by selecting desired indicators, markets, 
periods, and frequency. The users can also view, create and download online charts based on 
data selection criteria. In addition, the current TA also meets users’ data demand for foreign 
capital flows. ABO launched a new product, the monthly debt roundup, an infographic that makes 
it easy for users to get relevant information. Surveyed users and ABMI task force meetings have 
received the revamped website under the TA 9404: Supporting the Development of Asian Bond 
Markets through AsianBondsOnline  well, but some stakeholders suggested that ABO should also 
publicize work under other ABMI task forces to form synergy among ABMI efforts. The demand 
for synchronized information reflects users’ desire to obtain all the information they want from a 
one-stop website. Thus, the TA will echo the users’ demand and strengthen synergy among ABMI 
task forces to better serve stakeholders. 
 
11.  In response, to add more value to ABO as an information portal, the TA will follow the 
ABMI road map and upgrade ABO to become an integrated information platform for regional bond 
markets. In particular, ABO will synchronize bond market information and knowledge products 
and services from all ABMI activities; ABO’s enhanced website structure and information sections 
will  enable  users  to  easily  access  all  relevant  information  about  regional  bonds  markets 
development in one stop. The upgraded ABO will promote synergy among all ABMI task forces 
and, thus, better serve investors and improve investor awareness about ASEAN+3 bond markets. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcomes 
 
12.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: investor awareness of regional bond markets 
enhanced .5 The TA will have the following outcomes: (i) access to information on regional bond 
market improved and (ii) knowledge of regional bond market development promoted.6 
 
5   ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific.

Map, 2019–2022. Nadi

B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
13.  Output 1: Dissemination of information on ASEAN+3 bond markets strengthened. 
The TA will revamp ABO to be a regional bond market information platform by including new 
sections that disseminate information on all aspects of ABMI activity, including bond demand, 
bond  supply,  market  infrastructure,  and  cross-border  collaterals.  Under  the  TA,  ABO  will 
coordinate with other ABMI task forces to reflect up-to-date market status and progress. For 
example, the revamped ABO portal will launch an Asian green bond section, collaborating with 
the green bond TA7 under ABMI Task Force 1 to disseminate new green bond market practices 
and recent demand and supply information to attract more investors to regional green bond 
markets.  Another new section will serve as the online gateway to the ASEAN+3 Bond Market 
Forum under ABMI Task Force 3. The ABO website will publicize information, when possible and 
needed, for all other activities under all four ABMI task forces. In addition to new contents and 
features, ABO will continue to disseminate bond market data and enhance its website design and 
interface to improve user experience. ABO will also coordinate with the web team of ADB’s 
Department of Communications to ensure smooth navigation and maximize outreach. 
 
14.  Output 2: Knowledge sharing about ASEAN+3 bond market increased. The TA will 
continue to provide knowledge products and knowledge services to increase knowledge sharing 
and broaden and deepen the understanding of ASEAN+3 LCY bond markets. The TA will deliver 
three market-relevant knowledge products: (i) the quarterly ADB flagship report Asia Bond Monitor, 
(ii) a monthly debt roundup, and (iii) weekly debt highlights. Asia Bond Monitor provides updated 
market summaries and in-depth analysis of trending issues in regional bond markets. The monthly 
debt roundup is an infographic report that updates readers on changes in financial conditions, 
capital flow patterns, and monetary stances in the region. The weekly debt highlights appear in a 
weekly  newsletter  that  offers  users  the  latest  news  on  regional  bond  markets.  ABO  will 
disseminate the knowledge products mainly by digital publication but will make printed copies 
available upon user request. For example, some users—such as libraries, embassies, resident 
missions, financial institutions, and those with inconvenient internet access—may request hard 
copies occasionally. The TA will also enhance regional knowledge sharing through annual 
capacity-building workshops tailored to the host market’s bond market development needs. Based 
on the host market’s priorities and strategies, each workshop will mobilize knowledge across the 
region to share experiences, lessons, and expertise. This exercise will foster regional knowledge 
sharing and contribute to harmonization and collaboration within the region. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Investment Climate Facilitation Fund (ICFF)  under the Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Financing Partnership Facility and administered by ADB.8 The key expenditure items are in 
Appendix 2: Cost Estimates and Financing Plan. 
 
16.  The ICFF will finance capacity-building workshops, minimal equipment, the dissemination 
of knowledge products, and recruitment of consultants. All items in Appendix 2 are eligible for 
ICFF financing and in accordance with ICFF guidelines, with non-consultant costs not exceeding 
30% of the total TA cost.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA through the Macroeconomic Research Division (ERMR) of 
ADB’s Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department. ERMR will (i) be directly 
responsible for TA administration and supervision, management of consultants, procurement, and 
accomplishment of outputs; (ii) procure goods, disseminate knowledge products, and organize 
conferences, trainings and/or workshops; (iii) provide staff to act as the resource persons for 
conferences, trainings, and workshops; and (iv) monitor TA implementation.9 
 
18.  Implementation will be in accordance with the Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Financing Partnership Facility: Implementation Guidelines for Investment Climate Facilitation 
Fund.10 ERMR will implement the TA from September 2020 to June 2023 in consultation with the 
Economic  Research  and  Regional  Cooperation  Department’s  Financial  Cooperation  and 
Integration Team, ASEAN+3 government officials, and ADB’s Southeast Asia Department.

21.  ADB’s  procurement.  The  TA  will  use  direct  procurement  for  database  services

credit spreads for all markets; key financial market condition indicators; and government and

22.  Social media and websites. Timely updates of ABO’s databases and information are an 
integral part of the TA project’s implementation. If there is demand for the website to continue 
indefinitely, ERCD will explore alternative sources of financing to maintain it before project closing. 
 
23.  Cofinancier requirements. In accordance with ICFF guidelines, all TA outputs will ensure 
the visibility of the assistance from the Government of Japan. TA publications will explicitly state 
that they are the outcomes of a TA project funded by the ICFF of the Government of Japan. The 
Japan  Official  Development  Assistance  logo  will  appear  in  the  ABO  website  and  in  all 
dissemination materials for knowledge events and capacity development activities. The TA will 
tap  and  invite  Japanese  institutions  and  experts  as  co-organizers,  resource  persons,  or 
participants in TA knowledge events and knowledge services, not limited to capacity-building 
workshops and Asia Bond Monitor launch events. There are no additional monitoring and 
reporting procedures under the ICFF, as the fund follows ADB’s standard policies, procedures, 
and guidelines, as amended from time to time.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$2,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the 
Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Financing  Partnership  Facility  for  Enhance 
AsianBondsOnline as the Primary Bond Information Platform in ASEAN+3, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.
